transcript_segments.text: Today we’ll see a superb Kerala-style mutton biryani recipe. In this Malabar-style biryani, first the mutton is well cooked with a gravy, then the rice is fried, and finally both are layered and cooked on dum to make a delicious mutton biryani.

instruction: Boil water in a large pot, add salt and whole spices (cardamom, cloves, cinnamon, bay leaf). Add soaked rice and cook until it is 90% done. Drain the rice and set it aside.
title: Cook the Rice

transcript_segments.text: Let’s see how tasty Malabar biryani is made. First, we take a pressure cooker and add 750 grams of mutton. Then we add whole spices, pepper powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix everything well and cook the mutton.

instruction: Heat oil and 2 tablespoons of ghee in a deep pan. Fry the thinly sliced onions on medium heat until golden brown and crispy.

instruction: Remove half of the fried onions and set them aside for garnishing later.

instruction: In the remaining oil, add whole spices (if not already used in rice) and sauté briefly until aromatic.

transcript_segments.text: We sauté this well for a couple of minutes. Then add tomatoes, some fresh coriander leaves, mint leaves, and curd. Also add a little salt.

instruction: Add ginger-garlic paste and slit green chilies. Sauté until the raw smell disappears.

transcript_segments.text: We sauté this well for a couple of minutes. Then add tomatoes, some fresh coriander leaves, mint leaves, and curd. Also add a little salt.

instruction: Add the remaining fried onions back into the pan and sauté for a few minutes until soft and well-mixed.

instruction: Add chopped tomatoes, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and coriander powder. Cook until the tomatoes are soft and oil starts separating from the masala.
title: Add Tomatoes and Spices

transcript_segments.text: Add garam masala and some pepper powder. Mix well. Cook the tomatoes until they soften completely. After cooking for a couple of minutes, the tomatoes become soft and the gravy thickens.

instruction: Lower the heat and stir in the yogurt. Mix well to form a thick gravy base.

transcript_segments.text: Add garam masala and some pepper powder. Mix well. Cook the tomatoes until they soften completely. After cooking for a couple of minutes, the tomatoes become soft and the gravy thickens.

instruction: Add the chicken pieces. Mix to coat them well with the masala. Cover and cook until the chicken is tender and cooked through.

transcript_segments.text: Add garam masala and some pepper powder. Mix well. Cook the tomatoes until they soften completely. After cooking for a couple of minutes, the tomatoes become soft and the gravy thickens.

instruction: Uncover and continue to cook until the gravy thickens and clings to the chicken.

transcript_segments.text: While the gravy is cooking, the mutton will also be done. Release the pressure and add the mutton to the gravy. Squeeze in half a lemon for tanginess. Mix the cooked mutton into the gravy.
The mutton is already nicely tender. We won’t cook it further, just simmer it in the gravy for a couple of minutes. Then, we’ll prepare the rice. Mix the mutton in the gravy once again before that.
We had fried some onions earlier for garnish, so now we’ll add those birista onions. Since we pressure-cooked the mutton earlier, it’s already soft. We won’t cook it more, just mix and let it rest.

instruction: Grease the bottom of a heavy-bottomed pot with a little ghee. Spoon in half of the chicken masala as the first layer.
title: Prepare for Layering

transcript_segments.text: To prepare the rice, heat a pot, add ghee and oil, then add half an onion and sauté well. Add cumin seeds, and now add the jeerakasala rice (small-grain aromatic rice), about half a kilogram.

instruction: Add a layer of cooked rice over the chicken. Sprinkle fried onions, chopped mint, coriander leaves, lemon juice, and a drizzle of ghee.
title: Layer Rice and Garnishes

transcript_segments.text: To prepare the rice, heat a pot, add ghee and oil, then add half an onion and sauté well. Add cumin seeds, and now add the jeerakasala rice (small-grain aromatic rice), about half a kilogram.
Add the rice and sauté it for 2–3 minutes. In Malabar biryani, the rice is also lightly fried first. After frying for 2–3 minutes, add hot water to cook the rice.
Now we’ve added hot water along with some coriander leaves, mint leaves, and a couple of green chilies. Cook the rice fully, 100%. As you can see, the rice is nicely cooked now.

instruction: Repeat layering with remaining chicken, rice, and garnishes. Ensure the final layer is rice topped with fried onions and herbs.
title: Repeat Layers

transcript_segments.text: Once the rice is fully cooked, layer it over the mutton gravy. Top it with fried onions, coriander and mint leaves for garnish, and add a few dry fruits like cashews and raisins.

transcript_segments.text: After 5 minutes of dum cooking, a superb Malabar mutton biryani will be ready. It tastes absolutely amazing, especially when made with jeerakasala rice. The yakhni is also prepared differently, giving it a unique taste.

It’s really enjoyable to eat. The mutton is super soft. And since we first fried the rice and then cooked and layered it on the yakhni and gave it a dum, the rice has absorbed all the flavors perfectly.
